Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2011 07:10PM luvmywife wrote: Wow, My beautiful wife just fought that battle. In feb it was two brain mets, very small, then we found it in the lungs- i/we didn't stop there trying to figure this out- we were days from wbrt beginning when our third or 4th opinion said a spinal tap would be in order. Most dr's felt my wifes brain mets were too small for the horrible headaches she was having. As bad luck would have it, the cancer was in the spinal fluid as well. My wife never wanted to know prognosis. She wanted to fight and she was going to kick this craps Ass! We had an omaya port installed in brain- and chest port to get on with the fight. (Once it was in spinal fluid- we were told wbrt was not a good option) (may be a difference between spinal lesions and cells in fluid). The pain and nausea was horrible and one treatment of chemo to brain- I asked my wife if getting rid of pain and nausea would be better than this hell and going home (forget the dam cancer)- she said "now that's a fight worth fighting for. Three days later the pain mgmt team, nurses, and her and I worked together to carefully balance pain meds with allowing her dignity and ability to communicate. When she woke me at 5 am (I was sleeping in hospital in her room on the couch)- she said - its a miricle- no pain and no vomiting!! Am I cured? I told her yes it was a miracle, the cancer is still there - but let's go home! You never saw such a smile and so much love. For a period of time- all the pain and fear had faded into the background and my wifes beautiful "spunk" and "Love was back" I got her home- learned all her meds including her insulin and began taking care at home. 5 days later at 6:33 am, she had waited for me to wake up. I held her hand and let her know it was ok to go off to heaven and she quietly and peacefully went to heaven. Your doing the right thing. The decision is really your friends to make. The importants of dignity for the sick is so very very important. At least in our case- we found tHat precious miracal of no pain but it took a bit of a fight. Remember- miracles do happen!! I promised my wife and she said if I we simpy share our story and it helps someone else- the battle would not have been in vain. Good luck to you, your friend, your friend and prayers to each and everyone on this site. Such courageousness (sp) and friendships are so special

Her love for fishing and the fla Keys began on our honey moon when a Norwegion Capt Joe Johanson took us tarpon fishing. (Up to 100 lbs or more). I had known Capt joe for 20 yrs prior. Last Tuesday, rather than Thanksgiving, in the middle of the Tarpon season, our son, brother in law, and I and Twenty five friends on 5 boats laid her to rest. A beautiful prayer was said by another close Capt "Big Wave Dave" who also became part of our family in the last 6 yrs. Two beautiful songs were played (one our wedding song by Brian Adams- Everything I do I do it for you-our wedding song). So many flowers and a wreath were laid on the water they spread 100 yards. In the days preceeding the ceremony, we fished Amy's favorite "tarpon hole" and we caught four tarpon, one for me, one for Capt Big Wave Dave, one for our son, and one for her Brother!! I know she was smiling with this!! Then we had her celebration of life immediately afterwards. Now Amy is at peace where she so loved. Boy what emotions and thoughts went through my mind. I know she and Capt Joe were looking down from above with great joy. Thanks again to all who have been so supportive on this site and my prayers go out to all who need them from this ugly disease. I too, like Yan, would like to continue to update as my life adjusts and where I may be able to help some with our experience. Posts.Content: luvmywife wrote: My name is Mark. I lost my beautiful wife, Amy, on April 5, this year. Orig diag in feb 2010, clean scan in sept after lumpectomy, chemo, radiation. Dr told us we would "visit" surgeon in 3 month and onc 3 month later for first mamogram. No scans in plan. We asked what about scans and he said- oh if it comes back, it'll rear its ugly head in some physical way. How often and what type of scans, if any, should dr's be doing knowing we had tripple neg BC with 3 positive LN's out of 11? In my wifes case, 3 months after last radiation, she started getting headaches. Got treated for sinus infection first, the ct scan to head- showed no sinus infection.(Or anything else) Sent to neurologist who tried migrain meds but she said emergency MRI given BC history. MRI showed two brain mets but neurologist, radiologist all felt spots were too small for headaches my wife was having. So while we do brain MRI- they do Chest Ct scan- just as precaution. We find 8 mets to her lungs with evidence of fluid in lungs and ultmately C cells in plural fluid around the lung. My wife had no pain or physical symptons from lung mets. None- and still no idea what is causing her headaches. They gave her Decadron- steroid to lesson pain in head even though spots didn't show size to warrent. Headaches reduced partially not substatially. But still severe headches continued and whole brain radiation was being reccommended. I/we kept searching additional opinions. Find a great Parp Trial at lumbardie and finally got approved from our ins carrier. In the interim, sought one more opinion (4 th) from UVA. Long and short, this Dr was adamant wife's brain spots were too small for pain she was having. He suggested a spinal tap asap. If C cells were present there, treatment options change significantly. Spinal results take up to a week. We were at Georgetown to begin baseline test for trial when we find out cancer was in spinal fluid as well. So in early Feb (2011) We found brain mets only because of headaches cause by unknown sources. We found lung mets from precautionary scans (no physical pain or symptoms), on our own- we kept trying to find real cause for the headaches. Our ins co would not cover outside opinions. Unfortunately, our extensive and quick search for advice revealed a very difficult situation. At every step of the way, my wife took each set back with brave courage and unrelenting desire to not let this crap "take her". She never wanted a prognosis. She knew the fight was getting tougher at each step but she would not let these setbacks deter her will to fight and not leave her family. On April 5, God got my angel. Just 40 days after the brain met diagnosis- only a couple weeks from discovering the Cancer in the spinal fluid. She was 53 yrs old. I got her home. She was out of pain finally, she passed holding my hand looking into my eyes. We had a beautiful church service for her with so many friends and loved ones. Her/our passion was Tarpon fishing in the Florida keys. She wanted me to spread her ashes in the same spot where our best friend Capt Joe johansen and fishing guide for the past 15 yrs (beginning on our honeymoon) was laid to rest 2 yrs ago (also from cancer). God, I loved this women, her loss has been very tough for me, I know she wants me to move on while keeping all the beautiful memories close to my heart. I am blessed to have a great son, DIL, and two grandbabies. Laying her ashes to rest where she so loved to fish with capt Joe will be one last part of this very difficult journey for our family. We will have a party after laying her ashes to rest. That's what she wanted. All that being said, you'll note I joined this site in feb and did a lot of reading and research. I used private messaging with several who have been too kind with advice and comforting thoughts. My thanks and prayers go out to creators and members of this site it has been very helpful during this battle, which continues beyond my wife's passing. I promised my wife her death would not be in vain. I constantly wonder why regular scans after her last radiation- treatment were not part of treatment plan. I've heard protocol, I have heard it doesn't significantly change survival rate? Prayers to all Mark and Amy from above Dx 2/14/2011, DCIS, Stage IV, 3/11 nodes, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Her tumor is shrinking and she called me "tearfully" when her dr said he's having a tough time finding it!! I pray that with her youth and strength and help from above- she'll have a long healthy life! Thanks for letting me come back and share my journey. The kindness here is very special. Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2012 12:56PM luvmywife wrote: I just happened to see this post. At the very beginning of my wifes dx- I found this site. During her battle- what great help and advice I/we found here (on this site) to begin our stage IV fight. Unfortunately, it only lasted 40 days from her dx as Stage IV, After she became an Angel- same awesome support from this site. Thanks from the bottom of my heart. even today- As a husband of an Angel- for me- my wife Amy was my best source for "talk" or assurance that this fight was "our fight together". Most of the time it was not words said- but those not said that provided the strength for both of us. We just "knew". Next to her- it was her brothers, my own brother and some close friends and coworkers. I didn't have to seek the ones to share with-(when I needed support) they were there for me when I needed it and I knew it. They made theselves available- I knew they were there for me. There is a tougher part to this fight, or at least in my situation. The hardest part was those family members who for some reason seemed to hold me responsipble for the pain my wife was suffering- this was the most difficult part of this fight- even to this day. To them- it was something I did or didn't do causing my wifes pain. What ever decision Amy and I made- was hers first with my advice and complete support. Every descision we made for her treatment was always hers- but I gave her every darn bit of information I could gather. Its so difficult to think and make descisions when you are so tired and feeling so lousy. Together we did our best to make informed descisions together. Yet as hard as it was for me to believe- some family members seemed to/wanted to hold me responsible in some way responsible for the suffering my wife and best friend was going through. It was the doctor we chose, the treatment she had, the .... Top it off- how about a family member steeling checks and forging them from their dieing sister. Cashing them the day she passed, the day after and up to a month after. I am doing well with my grief. My Angel is there for me every day and so are those who were there during the fight. I will always miss my Angel but I know she's safe. We made a deal- I will share this with you all!! When we knew we were not going to be together on this earth for much longer, Amy said to me- "someone will live because of what I am going through." There is a reason I am taking so many hits ! "Everything happens for a reason" she would say. She took one hit after the other. As we were just approved for a trial at Georgetown Univ she said - maybe just maybe as I go through this medical trial- (never to happen as the two days later we found the cancer in her spine) some women will live!! You here on earth "honey", me in heaven, promise me- together we will not let this fight be in vain. Others will live because of what we are enduring!! Everything happens for a reason!! I love you and always will. Don't be sad!! Amy said... "This too will pass" Deal! Deal! As we both knew what was to come- yet never wanted to really acknowledge we were loosing our place together here on earth. We had important things yet left to do- me here on earth- her with God in heaven. The miracles began and still continue!! Hope this story helps! We all deal with this battle differently- God bless

She was and always will be a true example of true love and inspiration. She was and always be my best friend. For those who supported us and helped me/us with information, love, compassion-I /we will forever be greatfull. Thank you. Tonight I got a call for a donation for bc research. I said I had just given and they said- no you haven't. That must have been another group. I said- ok. Then they passed me on to the "verifyer". Something told me ask "how Much is going to this cause"?? She said we guarentee 10%. I was so upset. I told them, forget it, no way, don't call me back. Then I thought- check back with those who really care and ask nothing in return other than honesty and care. You wonder how many scams are out there! As I listened to the story they tell- then I tell them I lost my wife to bc- then you (I) was easy pickin. They knew, some list, I had given $ before. Something told me to ask!? Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2011 08:21AM luvmywife wrote: Wow- my wife, now an Angel faced a similar choice. We had only two small spots in brain. One deep one on out side of cerebellum. At first- dr's advised cyber knife. Then they found it in her lungs- and said wbr. Yet I found other dr's saying zap the few spots with Cyber knife and monitor. That was before they found it in her spine as well. Perhaps an MRI is in order- if there is no evidence of mets elsewhere- monitor may be an option. I felt our onc had no interest in the monitor option as that requires regular MRI's which is expensive. That's just from our experience. One dr said wbr and another said, without multiple brain mets, go with cyber knife and monitor. In our case- with lung mets and finally spinal fluid mets- our choices were then reduced to chemo to brain through omaya port. I am so sorry you are facing this choice. Ultimately, its thhe patients choice. God bless
